 Staff Appraisal Report Zimbabwe Rural District Council Pilot Capital Development Project I. INTRODUCTION 1.01 The project presented for approval is part of a larger and longer term program. This program is the Rural District Council Capacity Building Program. Henceforth, this larger program is cited as RDCCBP as it is widely referenced within the Government of Zimbabwe. For purposes of presentational clarity, the project presented for approval, the Rural District Council Pilot Capital Development Project, will be cited as RDC Pilot. 1.02 As will be explained in detail below, the RDCCBP is an ongoing Program composed of three components: Institutional Development; Human Resources Development; and Capital Development. The Government has requested Bank support for funding of a part of the Capital Development Component which will begin a five year program of investment in July 1997, corresponding with the beginning of GoZ financial year 1997/98. 1.03 Because of the mutually reinforcing nature of the three components of the RDCCBP, this appraisal covers the entire RDCCBP for the full five-year implementation period. At Government's request, the RDC Pilot is dimensioned to finance part of the Capital Development Component for the initial period from July 1997 to December 1999. The Government has requested that the Bank then provide unified support to all local authorities in Zimbabwe through the proposed Local Government Development Project (LGDP), building on the lessons learned and policy dialogue to be achieved under the RDC Pilot and the ongoing Urban 11 project (Loan 3079-ZIM) which is scheduled for completion in December 1998. The LGDP is expected to provide investment financing for about five years and will provide a vehicle of broad support to promote decentralization and reform in all of Zimbabwe's local authorities. 1.04 In Chapter III, The Program and the Project, Sections A-E present the RDCCBP Program, including Origin, Objectives, Description, Implementation Plan, Costs and Financing Plan. Sections F-I present specific arrangements for the RDC Pilot, covering Project Financing Plan, Disbursement, Procurement, Accounts and Audits. Finally, Sections J-M analyze the Economic, Environmental, Poverty and Risk aspects of both RDCCBP and the RDC Pilot Project.
 2 II. THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT SECTOR A. Zimbabwe's Local Government Structure 2.01 At Independence in 1980 Zimbabwe inherited a system of local government sharply divided on racial grounds. The system consisted of, on the one hand, Rural Councils and Urban Councils for the white settler population and, on the other, African Councils (later District Councils) for the majority black population. Furthernore, the two types of local authority had different parent ministries, with Rural and Urban Councils coming under the Ministry of Local Government and Town Planning, whilst African Councils came under the Ministry of Internal Affairs. 2.02 Since independence the Government has been committed to the establishment of a unified local government system, to replace the racially based dual system inherited from the previous regime. The 1988 Rural District Councils Act provided the legal basis for the amalgamation of the two previous types of councils into a Rural District Council. The amalgamation process involved various changes in administrative boundaries, in council structures and procedures, and also the amalgamation of the two local authority associations into a single Association of Rural District Councils (ARDC). In implementing these changes both the Ministry of Local Government, Rural and Urban Development (MLGRUD) and the ARDC received considerable donor assistance, particularly from the Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA), in the field of training and consultancy. 2.03 The intention of Government in establishing the RDCs was not only to amalgamate the two types of local authority but also to strengthen the role of local government in rural areas. Therefore, as part of the preparations for their establishment, MLGRUD, with financial support from SIDA, set up a special consultative body known as the Forum for Rural Development, to facilitate 'strategic dialogue' between major stakeholders concerned with amalgamation and rural local government in general. Over a three year period (1991-94), the Forum addressed a number of key policy and legislative issues and sponsored several studies on ways of increasing both the functions, resources and capacity of the new RDCs. The Forum commissioned consultancy studies for: Road Planning, Construction and Maintenance; District Health Provision; Education Service Provision; Financing of RDCs; and a Strategic Plan for RDC Capacity Building. 2.04 The reports of most of these studies are still under discussion, although the Strategic Plan for RDC Capacity Building has now been adopted by the government and forms the basis upon which the current national RDC Capacity Building Program has been designed.
 3 2.05 The creation of a unified system of rural local authorities was formally achieved in 1993 with the implementation of the RDC Act, five years after its promulgation. The amalgamation of all the rural authorities into Rural District Councils signals an important attempt to decentralize the system of governance, opening the door to a major shift in the management and provision of local services in rural areas from central to local government. 2.06 Each RDC falls within the territory of one Province. There are eight Provinces with RDCs within them-- the ninth and tenth Provinces are special cases of the national capital, Harare, and the second largest city in the country, Bulawayo, which have both City Council and provincial status. Provinces are territorial jurisdictions of the Central Government. Provincial Governors are appointed by the President, and each has a seat in the national parliament. The provincial administrative structure includes offices of line ministries, with these under the overall supervision of the Provincial Administrator who is appointed by the Ministry of Local Government, Rural and Urban Development (MLGRUD). Some line ministry offices extend down to the District level, and these are supervised by the District Administrator, also appointed by the MLGRUD. The District Administrator chairs the Rural District Development Committee (RDDC), and this Committee is charged with the responsibility of preparing and monitoring annual and long-term district development plans. The annual district development plan is approved in a joint session of the RDDC and the RDC. Although the RDC holds a prominent position in the RDDC, the RDDC also includes all district heads of sector ministries. At present, there is some debate about the role of traditional leaders in the RDDC. 2.07 The RDC Act mandates a committee structure, and each council must have, among others, a Ward Development Committee (WADCO) for each of the Wards (generally about 20-40 wards per RDC). In turn, each WADCO has representation from each Village Development Committee (VIDCO) within its jurisdiction. The WADCO is responsible for preparing and submitting its ward development plan, incorporating VIDCO and other interests, to its RDC. Finally, the RDC is responsible for consideration of all ward plans, and preparation and implementation of district development plans. These plans are the primary input of the RDCs into the annual district development plans approved by the RDDC. I B. Roles and Responsibilities of Rural District Councils (RDCs) 2.08 The RDC Act provides a legal basis for RDCs to assume responsibility for a number of key service areas. These include: overall development planning, education, I Additional information on the planning and administrative structures of Provinces and RDCs may be found in A. H. However, it is not yet possible to state precisely which functions RDCs will be responsible for in the future as the division of roles and responsibilities between central and local government is still being negotiated. The likelihood is that rural service provision will continue to be the dual responsibility of central and local government. Furthermore, even if RDCs take the lead for those functions listed above, many of them lack the skills and resources required, giving added impetus to the formulation of a national capacity building program. 2.09 The current capacity of RDCs to tackle the 64 tasks which the 1988 Act enables them to undertake is extremely varied, reflecting the different human, financial and physical resources inherited by RDCs from their predecessors. Moreover, the natural resource and economic bases of the RDC areas are extremely heterogeneous. Therefore needs, and the ability of RDCs to meet them, also vary significantly. However, on the basis of evidence from field experience and consultancy studies, a number of key weaknesses and gaps common to most RDCs can be identified. These can be classified into two groups: first, financial and human resources, as well as lack of vehicles and equipment; and second, organizational characteristics, involving leadership qualities and the organization's sense of mission, management systems and structures, and the degree of discipline, openness and accountability within the organization. C. RDC Financing 2.10 The financial base for RDCs is currently as follows. a) Central government grants which include a per capita grant from the ministry of education, an expenditure grant from the ministry of health and a small administration grant from MLGRUD. RDCs also receive small grants from the Natural Resources Board for activities related to land conservation. b) A range of local revenue sources including development levies, unit taxes, license fees, service charges, beer levies, royalties and revenue from income generating projects. c) Various public sector programs channel capital investment funds to RDC areas through sector ministries. d) Various loans are available, including from the National Loans Fund, the Central Rates Fund and the General Loans Fund, but these are not easily accessed by most RDCs. 2.11 RDCs are generally dependent on government grants, although the picture is variable. In some cases grants make up more than 60% of total RDC income, although in most cases the figure is around 40%. Administration grants, on average, make up about 35% of RDC administration expenditure; education grants make up about 50-60% of education expenditure while health grants make up almost 90% of health expenditure.
 5 2.12 In recent years central government grants have decreased as a proportion of total RDC income, implying an increased importance for local revenue. However, RDCs are far from assuming fiscal autonomy and this situation will not change in the near future. Fifty percent of RDCs surveyed for the Strategic Plan for Capacity Building had local revenue of less that Z$3 million in 1993/94, and 56% did not have sufficient local revenue to meet recurrent expenditure. 2.13 There are several reasons for this. First, the revenue raising powers available to RDCs are limited in number and in terms of their revenue raising capacity, since most significant powers rest with central government rather than local authorities. Second, central government exerts considerable influence over the level of revenue raised by RDCs. Third, many RDCs do not use their existing revenue raising powers as effectively as they might due to poor understanding of their rights and poor financial management. Finally, in many RDCs the scope for increasing local revenue is limited because of few opportunities for economic development and therefore low levels of income for the majority of the population. 2.14 RDCs should play a significant role in implementing capital development at district level. A survey by the consultants engaged for the Strategic Plan for Capacity Building found that in 1993-94, 19% of RDCs surveyed spent no money at all on capital development while a further 43% spent less that Z$0.5 million. Furthermore, 36% of RDCs spent no money on road maintenance while another 47% spent less than Z$ 1.0 million, and this includes RDCs with commercial wards where local authorities are responsible for road maintenance. 2.15 This low level of capital expenditure is due to the fact that although funds for RDCs are available from a number of sources, the amounts given tend to be very limited. Most government and donor funds for capital projects, with the exception of some Integrated Rural Water Supply and Sanitation (IRWSS) projects, are channeled through line ministries rather than RDCs. Few RDCs have the resources necessary to fund capital projects; indeed many cannot finance their own recurrent budgets. There is no access to loan facilities, other than housing development loans which have sometimes been beyond the capacity of poorer RDCs to repay. Some RDCs have been granted borrowing powers by central government mainly for housing schemes at growth points, Rural Service Centers or small towns. However, the majority of the RDCs have yet to qualify for these loans. D. Key Issues 2.16 The key issues confronting RDCs derive from two main sets of circumstances. First, the reorganization of responsibilities and authority inherent in Government's decentralization program present RDCs with a variety of ambiguities related to manageable priorities for service delivery. Transfer of responsibilities and resources to
 6 RDCs and other levels of local government should be undertaken in accordance with a coherent strategy founded upon a broad consensus. Government has taken significant steps during the past 12 months to establish such a strategy, but the multiplicity of central agencies involved in the decentralization process--and the obvious vested interests inherent therein--necessarily entail a gradual approach to consensus building. Therefore, a key factor in clearly defining a national decentralization strategy will be the degree to which RDCs can accept new responsibilities and provide required services on a sustained basis. 2.17 This raises the second set of key issues relating to RDCs' capacity to plan, implement and manage delivery of infrastructure and services. In the general absence of such capacity, consensus is unlikely to form among central agencies that meaningful decentralization should be undertaken. On the other hand, the installation of such capacity within RDCs in the absence of significant resources would be both a fruitless and frustrating enterprise. Further, given the diversity of existing capacities and priorities for local development among the country's RDCs, a monolithic approach to capacity building would be inefficient and, in many cases, nonresponsive. 2.18 Thus, the key issues are to link tailored capacity building within RDCs with access to resources in order to establish the strategic areas upon which a responsible program of decentralization should focus. In turn, these efforts at the local level must feed into the national consensus building process in order that transfer of central responsibilities, authority and resources is carried out in a manner which will lead to more equitable, sustained development. E. Strategy for the Local Government Sector 2.19 MLGRUD and the Bank are in full concurrence as to the appropriate assistance strategy, given the key issues as discussed above. This strategy explicitly recognizes that RDCs are a key target for capacity building in support of the decentralization process, but that continuing support to other local authorities must also be provided in order that the entire local government sector is empowered to play its fullest, most efficient role in promoting national development. For this reason the overall sectoral strategy emphasizes coordinated support to all local governments in Zimbabwe, including capacity building, access to capital resources and policy reform. The proposed RDC Pilot project will, as explained in Chapter I, provide capital to complement capacity building over an initial two year transitional period. During this period, the ongoing Urban II project will be completed and the proposed Local Government Development Project (LGDP) will be designed, with implementation initiated to provide continuing support to the entire local government sector in Zimbabwe. 2.20 The proposed project would extend the Bank's involvement with Zimbabwean local government to include the 57 Rural District Councils. This new and highly complementary initiative will build upon the Bank's long track record of support to
 7 Urban Councils, beginning with the Urban I project (Loan 2445-ZIM, approved in June 1984) and continuing with the ongoing Urban II project (Loan 3079-ZIM), expected to be closed in December 1998. A key lesson learned has been that Zimbabwe's local governments have the initiative and capacity, given adequate support, to improve their performances and assume increasing responsibilities as a key part of the decentralization process. 2.21 The Government announced a significant and comprehensive decentralization policy in July 1996. Under this policy, local governments--particularly RDCs--are to gradually receive significant additional infrastructure and service delivery responsibilities, as well as additional financing responsibilities. Although the Government's policy statement represents a consensus across all ministries on decentralization policy objectives and principles, implementation details remain to be worked out. A key element of the Bank's assistance is support to implementation of the policy, ensuring that international experience is brought to the benefit of Zimbabwe's decentralization process. 2.22 In summary, the strategy for the local government sector is to build on lessons learned from past and on-going initiatives, to support the Government in its sensible decentralization policy, and to initiate a new series of projects. This series would be initiated by the proposed RDC Pilot and followed by the LGDP. The strategy is designed to support (i) policies agreed with the Government, (ii) local government strengthening, and (iii) the sustainability, efficiency and equity of infrastructure and services increasingly under the responsibility of local governments. F. Rationale for Bank Involvement 2.23 Without the institutional and financial capacities to absorb new responsibilities at the local level, decentralization initiatives may be inefficient from the perspective of service delivery, as well as potentially destabilizing during a period of fiscal retrenchment. The proposed project would provide an opportunity for the Bank to support not only RDC capacity building and infrastructure financing, but also to contribute to the dialogue on decentralization and intergovernmental fiscal policy across sectors and between levels of government in the context of fiscal sustainability. 2.24 Government already has launched the RDC Capacity Building Program and is committed to its expansion. The effort has attracted significant donor support (UJNDP, UK, Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark), and the Bank has been invited to participate in an on-going effort. The Bank's support to the program is viewed widely as critical to its success, primarily for two reasons: (a) to provide investment funding as an incentive for institutional and human resource strengthening (financed by other donors) on a broad and substantial scale; and (b) to bring international best practices to the policy dialogue on decentralization.
 8 2.25 Given both its long-standing involvement with local governments in Zimbabwe and its broad experience in supporting decentralization throughout the developing world, the Bank is uniquely positioned to play a catalytic role in supporting the emerging decentralization process in Zimbabwe. The commitment of substantial bilateral support for "soft" capacity building activities will allow Bank funding to be focused upon its most appropriate application: capital investments. At the same time, the wealth of Bank experience in comparable decentralization exercises will assist Government in winnowing out the most efficient courses to be followed in defining Zimbabwe's way forward. In short, the combination in Zimbabwe of central government commitment, local authority willingness, bilateral support and clear focus for application of Bank resources presents a strong rationale for Bank involvement. G. Linkages to the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) 2.26 The 1994 CAS focused on four basic areas, including infrastructure to support growth and expand economic participation, and human resource investment and capacity building. The proposed project would support capacity building and infrastructure financing in the newly formed RDCs and is thus clearly consistent with the current CAS. A new CAS is to be presented to the Board in late May 1997. The new CAS calls for more selective support of the Government's development goals. One of the key features of the assistance strategy is greater use of pilot operations and adaptable project designs. The proposed project is a strong example of this, a pilot project incorporating innovative procedures to facilitate disbursements and promote learning-by-doing which will provide the Government with important lessons in the process of decentralization. The new CAS also highlights areas of focus for Bank efforts, including rural development and the development of human capital, both of which are supported in the proposed project. III. THE RDCCBP PROGRAM AND THE RDC PILOT PROJECT A. Program Origin and Participatory Design Process 3.01 The RDCCBP is a direct outgrowth of an extensive series of policy reforms, analyses, and pilot projects undertaken in Zimbabwe over the last seven years following issuance of the 1988 Rural District Councils Act. At the core of these actions has been the incremental approach taken by GoZ in articulating its decentralization policy which, for the rural sector, found particular focus through the Forum for Rural Development. 3.02 This Forum, which operated during the period 1991-94 under the leadership of MLGRUD with SIDA and Ford Foundation support, examined key areas in which RDC capacities and functions could be manageably expanded. Studies were undertaken in: a) Road planning, construction and maintenance;
 9 b) District health provision; c) Education service provision; d) Financing RDCs; and e) Strategic planning for RDC capacity building 3.03 MLGRUD complemented these policy studies with the initiation of the Pilot District Support Project (PDSP) in 1989 with ODA support in the Midlands province. The explicit purpose of PDSP was to test the degree to and pace at which improvements could be achieved in RDCs' capacity to plan, implement and manage infrastructure and service delivery. PDSP was, by 1994, judged to be a conspicuous success with the two pilot RDCs developing the capacity to successfully implement 69 infrastructure projects worth about US$820,000. Projects ranged from shallow wells valued on average at less than US$1,000 to district clinics requiring more than US$30,000 in capital investment. Under this project the RDCs worked successfully through a variety of implementing arrangements, including community-led initiatives, contracting out, force account, and implementation through line agencies. PDSP placed significant emphasis upon planning to achieve sustainable investments, with the result that in mid- 1996 all 69 of the infrastructure projects funded under the project were in operation and being maintained typically through contributions from the RDC and local residents. 3.04 With full amalgamation of all RDCs in 1993 and building upon the successful pilot project, MLGRUD has now moved to expand capacity building to include all RDCs in the country. Under the umbrella of the interministerial Capacity Building Coordinating Committee (CBCC), bilateral donors have demonstrated exemplary coordination in providing two years of support to the Capacity Building Unit (CBU) in MLGRUD which has carried out a systematic process of consultation with all RDCs and Provinces in designing the RDCCBP. B. Objectives 3.05 Within the context of government's overall decentralization program, the objective of the RDCCBP is to develop the capacity of all RDCs to plan, implement and manage the sustainable delivery of essential services. To achieve this objective, the program is explicitly designed to support learning by doing through the combined provision of institutional development support, human resources development inputs, and capital and material resources necessary to directly implement infrastructure and deliver services. 3.06 With the recently completed amalgamation of Zimbabwe's 57 RDCs, there exists for the first time in the country's history a complete framework of accountable, representative local authorities.2 This historic juncture presents Zimbabwe's first realistic 2 In addition to the RDCs, the local government system includes, in ascending order of complexity and authority, Town, Municipal and City Councils.
 10 opportunity to pursue a comprehensive decentralization agenda, and the RDCCBP is designed to support this agenda by focusing its assistance as directly as possible on the RDCs with Provincial level oversight. Ministerial input will, in turn, be focused on overall program management and policy reform. 3.07 Given the wide variance of human, financial and material resources existing in the RDCs, the program is designed to promote significant capacity improvement in all RDCs over the course of the RDCCBP (see Key Performance Indicators of Annex 1). As a way to "level the playing field" all RDCs will receive equal amounts of District Development Grants over the first two years of RDCCBP implementation (see Section C below). Thereafter, performance evaluations and poverty indicators will influence the magnitude of block grants available to councils, setting the stage for broader intergovernmental fiscal reform. 3.08 Key outputs expected under the program include: a) improved RDC planning, appraisal, implementation and technical supervision capacity; b) improved financial management and accountability; c) enhanced financial positions including improved local revenue generation; d) increased community participation in planning, implementation and management of development activities; e) improved provision and maintenance of economic and social infrastructure, and associated poverty reduction; f) enhanced public transparency and accountability of councilors and officials; and g) lessons leading to increased public/private partnerships in funding, implementing and managing infrastructure and service provision. 3.09 It must be emphasized that the overall program philosophy is one of learning by doing. This philosophy inherently assumes that mistakes will be made, analyzed and rectified to the ultimate benefit of participating RDCs and their constituents. While experience gained from previous projects such as PDSP and the Bank-assisted Urban I and II will clearly be of assistance in guiding RDCCBP implementation, the RDCs themselves will be entering uncharted waters in many respects and unforeseen outcomes are to be anticipated. Project Disbursements 3.48 The disbursement methodology to be adopted will play a key role in promoting the program's capacity building and decentralization objectives, and in setting the stage for broader reforms in the proposed LGDP. An essential element of Government's stated decentralization policy is movement of public investment decision making and management to the lowest appropriate levels in the country's political and administrative apparatus. The RDC Act provides the legislated basis for RDCs to plan and execute a
 23 wide variety of local public investments. Only through actual management of procurement and disbursement will the RDCs develop real capacity to responsibly deploy resources at the local level. However, the major constraint upon development of this capacity has been the absence, in all but a few RDCs, of significant capital finance. 3.49 Therefore, disbursements for financing RDC investments in civil works and goods will be made to Government against certification by the MLGRUD that (a) all participating RDCs have annual investment plans appraised according to the Project Operational Manual agreed with the Bank, and (b) the Government has approved the project investment financing (District Development Grants and Loans) included in the annual investment plans. Economic and Financial Analysis 3.61 The project is expected to benefit all 57 of the newly-formed RDCs through: (i) greater efficiency and equity in the delivery of infrastructure services, (ii) enhancement of decentralization of development planning, operation and maintenance responsibilities of the RDCs, and (iii) empowerment of local communities by reinforcing the "bottom- up" element of the district planning process. The impact of improved economic and social infrastructure would be both to raise the quality of rural life and improve linkages/reduce costs with local and provincial markets. Since the majority of Zimbabwe's poor (88 percent) live in rural areas, most of the benefits are expected to accrue to the poorer sections of society. 3.62 The small and dispersed nature of most of the possible sub-projects under this component coupled with the uncertainty regarding the exact composition of the capital investments make it impossible to quantify its expected rates of return using traditional cost-benefit calculations. In its stead, the benefits attributable to the typical sub-projects are qualitatively described. Typical sub-projects that are the top priorities of many RDCs include roads, water supply, education, and health and these are described below. Roads 3.63 The benefits from rehabilitation of rural roads will result from vehicle operating cost savings from reduced road roughness, benefits from savings in road maintenance costs, savings in accident costs, and benefits in terms of avoided higher costs of later reconstruction. Benefits will also be realized from time saving both of passengers and vehicle operators. In addition, improved/new roads will result in increased access of agricultural freight to markets, thereby potentially increasing farmers' incomes. There will be considerable variation between different RDC road investments due to factors such as terrain, level of economic activity, and population served.
 28 Water Supply 3.64 The main direct benefits of providing rural water sources that are closer, more reliable and more plentiful are savings in time and effort collecting water (especially for women), a healthier, more productive rural population due to increase in quantity and quality of water, improved health knowledge, better hygiene practices, and potential long- term medical cost savings through reduction in water-borne diseases. The availability of water could also lead to healthier livestock which are a critical socio-economic and cultural element of rural communities. For example, livestock census statistics in Gokwe district show that the Bungwa borehole funded under the PDSP has improved the general health of the local livestock, increasing the calving rate and increasing the potential off- take rate. Education 3.65 The returns to investment in education generate various benefits. "In-school" benefits include gains in the efficiency of the education system, per se. Out-of-school" benefits include improvement of the income-earning skills of the students and benefits that accrue to society at large beyond the project beneficiaries. A recent study7 has shown that returns to primary and secondary education in Zimbabwe are among the highest in the region. Health Clinics 3.66 Most indicators show that health outcomes in Zimbabwe are worse in rural than in urban areas. The under-5 mortality rate in 1994 was 80 in rural areas compared to 63 for urban areas.8 The most direct benefit of a health clinic in a community served by an RDC is the time-savings in the distance traveled (in some cases over 100 kms) by local residents to seek health care. Other potential benefits from such projects include: positive effects of reduced morbidity and mortality on productivity (fewer days lost from illness or disability, fewer worker days lost through premature death, less family time lost); consumption benefits (increased output of unmarketed household goods such as wood gathering, kitchen gardening etc., increased leisure, higher quality of life, reduced suffering to individual and other family members); greater efficiency of the school system, i.e., more efficient learning through saving of resources and higher future productivity due to better physical and mental development; and reduced household expenditures on medical care and supplementary food. 7 Psacharopoulos, G 1994. "Returns to Investment in Education: A Global Update", World Development, 22 (9), pp. 1325-1343. 8 UNICEF, 1994. Children and Women in Zimbabwe: A Situation Analysis Update 1994
 29 Cost Recovery and Sustainability 3.67 To ensure the sustainability of the RDC investments, the RDCs will be required to demonstrate how the operation and maintenance costs associated with a sub-project will be met. A sub-project like a school or health facility which requires GoZ financial and/or manpower support in order to operate will only be eligible for funding if it has the support of the relevant Ministry. Similarly, a project which will be operated and/or maintained by the RDC itself will only be eligible if the RDC can demonstrate how it will obtain the funds required to meet the recurrent funds thereof. Projects will also have to be properly appraised to ensure that the option chosen is the least-cost option, and that it is viable and justifiable. The Operational Manual requires that at least 10 percent of the grant be used to fund projects initiated and implemented entirely or largely by local community groups or organizations which will foster a greater sense of ownership among the project beneficiaries, thus contributing to the sub-project's sustainability. As required by the RDC Act, the district plan from which the sub-projects are derived are based on ward-level plans which in turn are based on some form of village-level plans. This is to ensure local-level participation in their preparation, a requirement that in conjunction with the community-initiated projects discussed earlier will enhance the project's overall sustainability. 3.68 Finally, benefits associated with the institutional development and human resources development components include: (i) Providing a framework for improved efficiency and effectiveness in planning, financial management, transport management, service provision, administration, co-ordination and teamwork; (ii) Increased local revenue generation in terms of efficiency of collection from existing sources and the development of new potential sources along with improving the fiscal and administrative skills of the RDCs; (iii) Strengthening the local government sector as an instrument for local decision making and influence of community residents; and (iv) Improved quantity, quality and cost-effectiveness of services which should result in better living standards in the communities served by the RDCs, and improved use of resources. Poverty and Social Impacts 3.70 In Zimbabwe, poverty is more prevalent in the rural areas (31 percent) than in urban areas (10 percent), and the overwhelming majority of Zimbabwe's poor (88 percent) live in rural areas. Communal farming areas house 77 percent of Zimbabwe's poor and 82 percent of the very poor (CSO, 19929 and World Bank, 199510). Economic benefits derived from improvements in quality, quantity, and cost-effectiveness of services (e.g., improved transport and access to markets, improved health, and access to water and sanitation) to the rural population will thus accrue more to the poorer groups than to the better-off. To the extent that the project contributes positively to stronger rural development, the employment impact will also be positive. 3.71 Rural women in Zimbabwe are known to spend significant time fetching water, some spending hours each day at the height of the dry season. If, as the initial beneficiary surveys suggest, water and sanitation investments are a top priority for the grants and loans provided under the RDC Pilot Project, the project should have a particularly salutary impact on women's welfare. 3.72 The project will contribute significantly to GoZ's efforts to reduce rural poverty by enhancing the provision of basic services. It is also expected to increase the responsiveness of local authorities to the needs of the community and to encourage greater community participation in the VIDCOs, WADCOs, and the District planning process. The project will aim to create a greater sense of ownership on the part of local communities for the projects that the RDC undertakes, thereby enhancing the cost- effectiveness and sustainability of service provision. The project will enhance accountability and transparency in the RDCs, enabling local communities to be better informed on key issues affecting their welfare, and promoting good governance. M. Risks and Safeguards 3.73 It should be recognized that this project presents significant risks. Political commitment to decentralization and strengthening local self-government appears to be strong now, but this may wane over time as political interests that stand to lose from effective decentralization may delay or derail the decentralization process. Both the Government and the World Bank will enter uncharted waters under this project, through increasing rural local government responsibilities and accountabilities. The main safeguard for this risk is the project's design as a pilot, with limited duration and credit exposure. In fact, these risks are inherent to the "learning by doing" process of the RDCCBP, and they should be mitigated by the Provincial Development Committee approval and monitoring process in general, and the presence of Provincial Support Teams in particular. Risks also should be mitigated over time (assuming that political commitment to decentralization policy is sustained) as lessons are learned and incorporated in the investment planning, implementation, operation and maintenance process. 3.75 From the perspective of Zimbabwe's longer-term development, however, the potential risks of this credit operation are commensurate with the potential development benefits.  Annex 3 Page 1 of 9 Annex 3 Environmental Analysis 1. Background. The Government of Zimbabwe (GoZ) has long supported the concept of sustainable development. The 1987 National Conservation Strategy (NCS) identified a number of serious environmental issues facing the country and various actions that were needed to address the problems. In 1992, the Canadian government established the 5-year $15 million Zimbabwe Natural Resources Management Programme (ZNRMP) to assist the GoZ in building capacity within the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET) to implement its NCS through a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP). The four main components of the ZNRMP in the MET include training; analysis and databases; environmental assessment; policy, planning and legislation. 2. Policy, Legal, and Institutional Framework. Prior to 1994, most of the Environmental Assessments (EAs) were conducted as a requirement of international donor agencies and multinational corporations. Following an official directive from the Cabinet to develop the necessary legislation and policy to implement effective management of natural resources in the country, the MET promulgated an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Policy in 1994.1 Currently, there are 21 pieces of conflicting and overlapping statutes directly or indirectly related to environmental management administered by at least 8 different Ministries. Some sector-based statutes, including the Natural Resources Act, the Mines and Minerals Act, and the Forestry Act, require EIA and stipulate measures for enhancing environmental conservation and preventing degradation. It is generally accepted that the environmental function of the MET has to be harmonized with the functions of other sectoral Ministries and governmental agencies, while ensuring that the MET is the umbrella Ministry responsible for overall formulation, implementation, and enforcement of environmental legislation. The MET has also recently completed a thorough analysis of environment-related legislation in the country, including a review of the major institutional issues surrounding the development of new legislation. A comprehensive Environmental Management Act is currently being drafted rationalizing the existing pieces of environmental legislation, and which would make EA mandatory. It is unclear whether the 1994 EIA policy would be incorporated into a separate law or would be part of the proposed Environmental Management Act. What is indubitable is that the Rural District Council (RDC) Pilot will be implemented in an institutional and legislative context for environmental management that is undergoing significant and positive reform. At present, this policy does not enjoy statutory status. 56

The types of sub-projects that are likely to be funded include minor works in water supply and sanitation, roads, clinics, schools, and other community facilities. A substantial proportion of investments is expected to be for rehabilitation. The net environmental impacts therefore probably will be either neutral, as in the case of conscientiously designed new roads, or positive, as in the case of provision of water supply and sanitation facilities. Additional positive environmental impacts may arise from the construction of community facilities which provide green spaces or public meeting areas with water and sanitation facilities. No resettlement is envisaged, and the project has been classified as Category B. 4. In the light of the above, this analysis is therefore confined to: (i) flagging potential adverse impacts ; (ii) presenting a simple questionnaire checklist that could be used by the RDCs to evaluate the environmental impact of proposed projects; and (iii) ensuring that the appraisal and monitoring of the RDC sub-projects are designed in such a way to ensure that each sub-project is properly assessed and monitored for potential environmental effects and dealt with on a case-specific basis. The generic impacts of the typical sub-projects identified by the RDCs as their top priorities are highlighted under each sub-sector as follows: 5. Rural roads. As the road works envisaged under this project would consist mainly of the upgrading and rehabilitation of existing secondary and feeder roads, no significant negative environmental impacts are anticipated. On the other hand, road rehabilitation can provide positive environmental impacts by encouraging traffic to remain on established roads, rather than using undeveloped alternative routes, rebuilding shoulders to increase safety, and repairing or modifying road alignment to improve drainage and run-off. The following points may need particular consideration, though: (i) Erosion and slope stability. Local erosion problems can be exacerbated and slope stability disturbed by road rehabilitation if not carried out properly. These can be the result of deficient drainage, modification of water flows, or through excavation for gravel and borrow materials. In most instances, potential problems can be avoided or mitigated through appropriate design or by taking measures such as backfilling or vegetative measures. (ii) Impact on the local vegetation/deforestation. Minor excavations/clearings may result in the clearance of vegetation increasing deforestation rates. In these cases, the problems can be mitigated through appropriate design and minimizing vegetative clearance. (iii) Cultural issues. The expansion of an existing road may endanger religious, spiritual, or archaeological sites. These problems can be avoided by consulting traditional leaders and avoiding sub-projects on such environmentally sensitive sites. 6. Water Supplv and Sanitation. In general, water supply and sanitation projects could be expected to yield positive environmental outcomes for the communities 57

Inadequate protection of the well or borehole surroundings could result in possible contamination of the water source. The risk of such contamination can be offset by proper design and construction of appropriate protective measures for the water source, and training of community members in appropriate maintenance practices. Provision of latrines could contaminate shallow groundwater resources which could be mitigated through relocating latrines or identification of alternative drinking water sources. Aggravation of sanitation problems from unsafe disposal of sludge can be mitigated by ensuring properly functioning arrangements for disposal of wastes in controlled sites. (ii) Use of water points for watering/grazing livestock. There is a possibility of overgrazing/watering of livestock leading to degradation of soil and vegetation around the water source. This can be avoided by providing alternate sources for watering livestock, and alternative pasture areas. 7. Social Infrastructure Proiects.  Annex 7 Page I of 4 Annex 7 Proposed Auditing Arrangements Backgrsond A key principle of the RDCCBP is the promotion of learning by doing among participating RDCs. With regard to the capital investment component of the program, it will be very important to ensure that adequate monitoring of the RDCs' management of DDGs and DDLs is carried out so that any difficulties can be identified, brought to the attention of the RDCs and rectified. The bi- and multilateral donors involved in funding the capital investment component must also have access to audit reports to support their contributions to the program. The challenge is to ensure that RDCs are assisted in their learning by doing by adapting audit requirements to both meet donor needs and support, rather than impose upon, the RDCs in carrying out their duties. Evaluation of the program's performance should, to both support capacity building and satisfy donor requirements, address a number of key areas including: --impact of investments --improvement in RDC planning, implementation and maintenance performance --financial accountability --central disbursement management. Following is a suggested approach to gathering necessary data for all of these areas without overburdening RDCs or diverting resources from their intended investment purposes. 1. Impact Assessment and Performance Evaluation- plans are already well advanced for a UNDP managed impact assessment baseline study. This study, as presently designed, will collect a wide variety of data from a sample of 8 RDCs (at least one from each province) over a multi-year period. This study will allow assessment of progress resulting from, particularly, the institution building component of RDCCBP. Included in this assessment will be evaluation of the performance of the selected RDCs in following the Operations Manual to plan, implement and subsequently maintain capital investments including those funded through the DDGs and DDLs. The Bank and bilateral donors financing the capital investment component of RDCCBP require evaluations of the performance of all 57 RDCs in managing these investments. Rather than commissioning a separate evaluation activity--which would consume significant time and resources--it would be more efficient to incorporate this evaluation into the UNDP managed baseline study. Since this study will be taking place in all 8 provinces, the additional workload to evaluate all RDCs with respect to the capital 96
 Annex 7 Page 2 of 4 component of the project should not be overwhelming. A draft scope of work for this activity is attached, and is proposed for inclusion in the baseline study TOR. 2. Financial Accountability- existing Government regulations require that all RDCs submit independently audited financial statements within nine months of the end of each financial year. These regulations are acceptable to the Bank. At present more than 30 of the RDCs are in compliance, but about 24 have significant backlogs of unaudited annual accounts. It is necessary, therefore, to provide directed assistance to these RDCs to clear their books and resume the mandated annual auditing regime. Funding for the technical assistance required to achieve this goal could be provided through the policy development component of the RDC Pilot project. This component, which is administered by MLGRUD through the CBU, could make available funding for RDCs to contract certified auditors to clear RDC books. Following this assistance, all RDCs would, as a condition of eligibility to receive capital grants and loans, be required to conform with established Government auditing requirements from financial year 97/98 forward. All RDCs would be required to pay for these audits from their own resources, and PSTs would monitor to ensure that satisfactory auditing arrangements are in place for all RDCs. This eligibility requirement should be incorporated in the RDCCBP Operations manual with the additional codicil that all RDC annual audited accounts must contain a specific assessment of RDC operation of the RDCCBP/Pilot Project capital investment account (this would not be an onerous requirement, amounting to little more than a few sentences). Since the task of clearing unaudited annual accounts can be fairly complicated, it will be necessary to secure specialized assistance to draft a Terms of Reference for this critical activity. CBU and the Bank will work together to secure this specialized assistance. Assuming that each problem RDC would require Z$ 100,000 to clear its books, about US$240,000 from the Pilot Project policy component would be earmarked for this purpose. 3. Central Financial Management- the remaining audit requirement would be for MLGRUD/CBU central management. A separate contract for this purpose will be necessary, and Bank assistance will be available in drafting the TOR. In summary, these combined approaches to auditing requirements would appear to satisfy both Government and donor requirements. It is very important that the Ministry assign a high priority to finalizing these arrangements so that RDCCBP and the Pilot Project can commence from a solid footing. 97

Monitoring Implementation of the DDG Operational Manual The DDG Operational Manual sets out very clearly the: --criteria for use of DDGs --procedures for DDG project identification and applications --appraisal at the RDC and Provincial levels --disbursement procedures --implementation guidelines --monitoring and evaluation at RDC, Provincial and National levels. The Provincial Development Committees (PDCs) and the Provincial Support Teams (PSTs) have primary responsibility for ensuring that the DDG Manual procedures are implemented by all RDCs. The PDCs and PSTs are well placed to carry out their respective review and facilitating functions. As direct participants, in support of the RDCs, in the DDG planning and implementation processes these bodies would benefit from periodic, independent assessments of the overall performance of the new system embodied in the Operational manual. In addition, independent performance evaluations would provide useful information to the CBU as well as bi- and multilateral donors which are financing the DDGs. The UNDP-managed program impact assessment study is designed to provide detailed information for a sample of RDCs in each province of Zimbabwe. The design of this study includes assessments after the first 6 and 12 months of RDCCBP operations, and annually thereafter for the life of the program. As such, the impact assessment provides a very useful vehicle to achieve assessment of the performance of all participating RDCs in implementing the provisions of the Operational Manual. 1. Scope of Work This additional task would be carried out within the overall impact assessment activity without adding an undue burden to either the assessment team(s) or the participating organizations. During each scheduled assessment in all provinces, selected members of the assessment team would verify the following information relating to implementation of the DDG Operational Manual as follows: 98
 Annex 7 Page 4 of 4 a. Review all annual work program (AWP) submissions from councils to RDCs to ascertain compliance with the Manual's provisions regarding project identification, application and appraisal. In a typical province, this would involve review of about 8 submissions requiring no more than several person days of effort. b. During each scheduled assessment period, the team would interview all (where each RDC is readily accessible) or a sample of RDCs in some detail regarding the planning processes adopted by those RDCs in framing their DDG proposals for the year. These interviews would focus upon the degree to which participation from key interest groups was included in the planning process, methods by which RDCs prioritized the investments proposed for DDG funding, and provisions made (budgetary and otherwise) by RDCs for efficient maintenance and utilization of the DDG funded investments. In provinces where interviewing only a sample of RDCs is required due to logistical considerations, care would be taken to ensure that the remaining RDCs are contacted in the subsequent scheduled assessment. Depending upon the province, these interviews might require an additional 10 person days per assessment. c. Beginning with the assessment scheduled for mid-1998, the scope would broaden to include review of RDC compliance with Manual provisions regarding procurement and disbursement. This additional sub-task should add no more than one person day to the interviewing task discussed in b. above. d. The assessment team would also specifically review the community-driven projects for which a 10% set aside is included in the DDGs. Of particular importance would be review of the project identification process to determine the means by which community initiatives are solicited and prioritized by RDCs for implementation. 2. Reporting A brief, separate report would be prepared by each provincial assessment team detailing findings for the items discussed above. These reports would be submitted to CBU for distribution. This report preparation would add approximately 10 person days of effort to each scheduled assessment. 3. Additional Level of Effort A rough estimate of the additional level of effort required for this task over the 2 year period corresponding to the RDC pilot project would be 140 person days. Assuming average fees and expenses of US$200/day, additional budget of US$30,000 may be required. This funding may be available from ODA; if not, provision from the RDC Pilot Policy Development component can be accommodated. 99

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Rural District Council Pilot Capital Development Project is to develop the capacity of all Rural District Councils (RDCs) to plan, implement, and manage the sustainable delivery of essential services. The program consists of the a) institutional and b) human resources development components complemented by b) the capital development component. The institutional development component will support improvements in the capacities of the RDCs to plan and sustain priority services and facilities as well as financing basic equipment acquisition. The human resources component is designed to build capacity to provide continuing human resources development assistance to the RDCs and to respond to specific needs. The capital development component will provide RDCs with access to grant funds necessary to a) reequip and reinitiate critical services and infrastructure; and b) provision and create incentives for improved RDC performance.
